items.title: By the time you hear these bats, it’s too late
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03515-5 The fringe-lipped bat ambushes its prey, helping to make it an exceptionally efficient hunter.

items.title: Increasing wintertime cloud opacity increases surface longwave radiation at a long-term Arctic observatory
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64441-8 Two decades of measurements at an Arctic research station reveal increasing wintertime radiative flux into the surface due to increasing cloud opacity, which is due to both ice-only and liquid-containing clouds.

items.title: On-target off-tumor toxicity of claudin18.2-directed CAR-T cells in preclinical models
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-61858-z Promising clinical activity of Claudin (CLDN) 18.2-directed CAR-T cell therapy in patients with gastric cancer has been recently reported, however gastrointestinal toxicities have also been described. Here the authors recapitulate the on-target off-tumor toxicity of CLDN18.2-directed CAR-T cells due to gastric mucosa damage in preclinical models, suggesting an AND-gate strategy targeting CLDN18.2 and mesothelin to overcome CAR-T cell toxicity

items.title: Modeling and addressing on-target/off-tumor toxicity of claudin 18.2 targeted immunotherapies
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65148-6 Claudin 18.2 (CLDN18.2) has emerged as a target for gastrointestinal cancer, however, on-target/off-tumor toxicities have been also reported. Here, after reporting evidence of erosive gastritis in patients treated with CLDN18.2 targeted immunotherapies, the authors develop and characterize CLDN18.2 fully-human VH-only single domain CARs, showing that a lower affinity CAR mitigates on-target/off-tumor toxicity while preserving anti-tumor efficacy in gastric cancer models.

items.title: Hotly debated dinosaur is not a tiny T. rex after all
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03561-z A key fossil suggests that the controversial Nanotyrannus is its own species, not a juvenile Tyrannosaurus rex.

items.title: T. rex debate settled: contested fossils are smaller rival species, not juveniles
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03552-0 New evidence answers the question about whether some fossils are Tyrannosaurus rex juveniles or a different species, with implications for decades of published science.

items.title: Daily briefing: The bowhead whale’s secret to living to 200
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03562-y A cold-activated protein protects the bowhead whale’s DNA from dangerous mutations. Plus, an elephant-inspired bioprinter and a new way to test the progress of artificial intelligence.

items.title: PEG alternatives for RNA therapeutics
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02408-2 Concerns associated with the immunogenicity of mRNA lipid nanoparticles containing polyethylene glycol (PEG) are inspiring the development of PEG alternatives.

items.title: Graphene grating lifts terahertz quantum cascade lasers into the Reststrahlen band
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02006-y A gallium arsenide-based terahertz quantum cascade laser harnesses graphene plasmons and optical nonlinearity to push the laser emission into the elusive far-end of the terahertz region.

items.title: Electrically driven heterostructured far-infrared wire lasers with integrated graphene plasmons
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02005-z A miniaturized frequency up-converted electrically tunable single-mode photonic source in the 9.0–10.5 THz range is demonstrated.

items.title: Superconductivity in substitutional Ga-hyperdoped Ge epitaxial thin films
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 30 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02042-8 The epitaxial growth of hyperdoped Ga:Ge films and trilayer heterostructures by molecular-beam epitaxy yield superconductivity with a critical temperature of 3.5 K and may enable quantum functionalities in this material system, which is accessible with well-established semiconductor technologies.
